p: The E. globulus essential oils here analyzed showed high contents of 1,8-cineole, followed by α-pinene, aromadendrene, limonene, α-terpinyl acetate, and globulol, listing the compounds according to their decreasing quantities. Comparing these values with those set out by Barbosa et al. [ 71], it can be observed that 1,8-cineole is always the most abundant compound, with values between 21.4 and 90.0% in essential oils from different countries. The rest of the main compounds analyzed in the studies shown by Barbosa et al. [ 71] do not follow a common pattern. However, it must be considered that the chemical composition of Eucalyptus essential oils depends on the plant stage, and consequently, the harvesting time has significant effects on the chemical composition of this oil [ 28].
